Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 09:35PM gumshoe wrote: Hi Barbiecorn - You might want to create a new post for this. I noticed the date is 2009! Sometimes I wish they'd archive old posts because I have done the same thing.
Posts.Title: Overwhelming fatigue 4 weeks after Mastectomy JenXX Olami

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2012 02:41PM - edited Aug 4, 2012 02:43PM by gumshoe Thanks everyone for the feedback! I don't think it was an IV or vein problem since I had the same one in when I woke up. Joanne -- Yes they always visit me too beforehand, and this one did too, but he also didn't have my previous file since it was a more urgent surgery (< 24 hours' notice), and in a different hospital. michellej -- I think that's what happened here. After reading up on this last night, Propofol is notorious for causing a lot of pain (the "Propofol Burn"). Most anesthesiologists mix it with lidocaine and feed it to you slowly so you don't feel it, but it takes longer to put you out. It would explain it (if indeed that's what they gave me), so I will find out next week.
Posts.Title: General Anesthetic: horrible pain in arm when being put under gumshoe christina0001

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2012 05:06PM gumshoe wrote: Well. Just to update even if it's a note to myself: I asked my PS the name of the anesthesiologist who worked with him that day. He hesitated, so I described the guy. "Oh," he said, "that was so-and-so." So I asked him whether he knew what the guy had given me that hurt so bad that I was yelling. His response: "Maybe you just thought you yelled. I didn't hear anything."  I told him I'd bet my left breast that I yelled loud enough for everyone in the OR to hear. So, I'm on a mission to find out, now more than ever.
Posts.Title: General Anesthetic: horrible pain in arm when being put under gumshoe christina0001

Posts.Content: gumshoe wrote: Just wondered if anyone else has experienced anything like this. I've had general anesthetic many times with no real issues. Usually I feel a very slight burning sensation in my arm as they're putting me out. Today, however, whatever the anesthesiologist put in the IV made me literally yell out in pain until I was asleep. It was horrible, like he had cut open my arm and poured acid into it. Somehow I think he must have missed a step. Has anyone else experienced this? Dx: 1/20/2012, DCIS, 3cm, Stage 0, Grade 3; Tx: lumpectomy, re-excision, skin-/nipple-sparing mastectomy (right), tissue expander placed, tissue expander removed due to skin necrosis, graft taken from thigh to replace lost skin. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 10:39PM gumshoe wrote: Thanks, Mods. Yes, I'm going to definitely follow up next week. In Canada, they operate independently from the surgeons -- I can't remember what his name was, so I'll have to do some digging. I cannot even describe the pain and panic I felt, and it has quite effectively turned me off any further surgery!

Posts.Title: Off to a breast surgeon Kareywith3littlekittens MomToFive

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 08:25PM gumshoe wrote: I have to chime in and say that I'd be very leery of letting anyone take a lymph node unless they was a clear reason to do so! I was given the option during my lumpectomy and I said no. The surgeon said that wasn't a problem since they could always go back in and take one if the diagnosis warranted it. Lymph nodes can swell for many reasons so I can't understand why he'd want to remove any if you haven't yet been diagnosed with anything.   Good luck..
Posts.Title: good lord I just realized there is a friggen tumor in my boob! nikkige85 Sommer43

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 02:57PM gumshoe wrote: I did use an ice bag wrapped in a towel -- it really helped with my pain. I was pretty swollen too. Really, it is quite an invasive procedure for a tender area. I have a pretty high pain tolerance and I needed pain meds for nearly 3 weeks!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 11:55PM gumshoe wrote: I was wide awake for mine, only local freezing, and it wasn't too bad. If you're under a general anethesia you'll be fine. You'll probably be in a little discomfort the next day and night (I took Tylenol 3), but I was feeling a lot better by the second day. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 04:02PM gumshoe wrote: I agree about the bras -- it's hard to find nice ones. My existing bras don't quite cover the breast form either but I might try having a pocket sewn into one of them once I'm completely healed. (I LOVE the breast form I bought -- you can't even tell it's not real!)  What I wear the most is an Amoena camisole. It's actually quite attractive, very comfortable, and it has a large, built-in pocket for the breast form. You could wear it in the summer without anything over it.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2012 12:31AM gumshoe wrote: Hi anamerty -- I am still not back to "normal" and I had a UMX in the beginning of August. Blessings is right -- and we all heal differently. (I love naps on a normal day, though :) Surgery is really hard on the body. And stress/worry adds to it all -- that was one of the biggest energy drains for me.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 01:40PM gumshoe wrote: Yes, Google isn't a good thing when you don't yet know what you are looking for! I do a lot of research for work so it's second nature to me -- but I MADE myself stay away from Google until after I was diagnosed   Please do keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Change in left breast size salsy gumshoe

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 01:08AM gumshoe wrote: Cindy: Yes, I agree that the camisoles are great. I had two so I could wear one and wash the other. (I had to wear mine 24 hours a day.) I've had multiple surgeries so I have gotten a lot of use out of them! I had steri-strips (which stayed in place for a few weeks) but not glue. I wasn't allowed to shower with my drains (just bird-baths) but the drains in general didn't really bother me as long as they were tucked into the camisole pockets. And at least we're coming into the colder weather so you can wear bulkier clothing!
